msgSnippet: This is a bug in the JVM implementation. So,  I don’t know about Red Hat, but with Blackdown, getting 255 instead of –1 is a missing cast in the JVM. In a

Subject: Re: [junit] Junit 3.4 + RedHat Linux 7.0 == 2 test failures?
To: junit@egroups.com
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
From: Kevin Kim <kykim@...>

This is a bug in the JVM implementation.

So,  I don�t know about Red Hat, but with Blackdown,
getting 255 instead of �1 is a missing cast in the
JVM.

In a JVM file (UNIXProcess.c??), the offend line
probably reads:
    exit_val = WEXITSTATUS(status);
it should read
    exit_val = (signed char)WEXITSTATUS(status)
or something like that.

Complain to the JVM implementor.

-kevin

on 12/12/00 19:08, Mike Greiner at
mikegreiner@... wrote:

Hello All,

I just unzipped junit 3.4 on my RedHat 7.0 linux box
(i386) and tried to run the sample tests to verify the
install. When run with Sun's JDK 1.3 I see the
following:

:-) >java junit.textui.TestRunner
junit.samples.AllTests
..........................................................................F.F...
Time: 16.399

FAILURES!!!
Test Results:
Run: 78 Failures: 2 Errors: 0
There were 2 failures:
1) testError(junit.tests.TextRunnerTest)
"expected:<-1> but was:<0>"
2) testFailure(junit.tests.TextRunnerTest)
"expected:<-1> but was:<0>"        


When run with the Blackdown 1.2.2 JDK it still fails,
but with an return value of 255 rather than 0:

:-) >java junit.textui.TestRunner
junit.samples.AllTests
..........................................................................F..F..
Time: 1.928

FAILURES!!!
Test Results:
Run: 78 Failures: 2 Errors: 0
There were 2 failures:
1) testFailure(junit.tests.TextRunnerTest)
"expected:<-1> but was:<255>"
2) testError(junit.tests.TextRunnerTest)
"expected:<-1> but was:<255>"     


I changed my path each time to pick up the desired
JDK. I'm on day 2 of my junit experimentation
(yesterday had good success with version 2.1 but I
wanted to check out the new stuff) so it's quite
possible I'm doing something wrong.

Version 3.4 seems to be working fine for the few tests
I've written myself, but I'd like the secure feeling
of seeing junit's own self-tests pass.

Suggestions?

Thanks much, Mike


P.S. Yes, for whatever reason, Blackdown's JDK 1.2.2
is much faster running these tests than Sun's JDK 1.3.
